title: Classes and Objects with Constructors/Destructors - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Computer Science - Lesson 18

questions.question: What is a class in C++?
options: A way to bind data and its associated functions together
questions.explanation: A class is a way to bind the data and its associated functions together. It allows data functions to be hidden, if necessary from external use.

questions.question: By default, the members of a class are:
questions.explanation: By default, the members of a class are private. The use of keyword private is optional. If the labels are missing, members are private by default.

questions.question: What is an object?
questions.explanation: An object is an instance of a class and it can be created by using class name.

questions.question: Which operator is used to access class members through an object?
questions.explanation: The dot operator is called the class member access operator. Through object, data member and member function present in public can be accessed using dot operator.

questions.question: The scope resolution operator is represented by:
questions.explanation: The operator '::' is known as scope resolution operator and is used to associate member functions to their corresponding class when defined outside the class.

questions.question: Variables declared inside a class are called:
questions.explanation: The variables declared inside the class are called as data members. The functions are known as member functions.

questions.question: Which visibility mode allows inheritance but restricts direct access by objects?
questions.explanation: The private and protected modes are exactly the same except that protected can be inherited but private mode cannot be inherited.

questions.question: What is nesting of member functions?
options: Calling a member function inside another member function of the same class
questions.explanation: A member function can be called by using its name inside another member function of the same class. This is known as nesting of member functions.

questions.question: What is a constructor?
options: A special member function that initializes objects automatically
questions.explanation: A constructor is a special member function that initializes the objects of its class automatically when it is created. It is special because its name is the same as the class name.

questions.question: A constructor has the same name as:
questions.explanation: A constructor is special because its name is the same as the class name. It is invoked automatically whenever an object is created.

questions.question: Does a constructor have a return type?
options: No, it does not have any return data type
Yes, it returns the class type
questions.explanation: Constructor does not have any return data type, not even void. Constructor should be declared in the public section and it cannot return any values.

questions.question: A constructor that accepts no parameter is called:
questions.explanation: A constructor that accepts no parameter is called default constructor. If no such constructor is defined, then the compiler supplies a default constructor.

questions.question: Constructors that can take arguments are called:
questions.explanation: The constructors that can take arguments are called parameterized constructors.

questions.question: Which statement correctly creates an object using parameterized constructor?
questions.explanation: When the object is created with parameterized constructor, we must supply arguments. The statement 'student S1(1, 70);' is the shorter and commonly used method.

questions.question: What is a copy constructor?
options: A constructor that takes no parameters
A constructor that takes multiple parameters
A constructor that takes a reference to an object of the same class
questions.explanation: A copy constructor takes a reference to an object of the same class as itself as an argument. It is used to initialize an object from another object of the same class.

questions.question: The process of initialization through a copy constructor is known as:
questions.explanation: The process of initialization through a copy constructor is known as copy initialization. For example: student S2(S1); or student S2 = S1;

questions.question: What is a destructor?
options: A member function used to destroy objects created by a constructor
questions.explanation: Destructor is used to destroy the objects that have been created by a constructor. The destructor is a member function whose name is the same as the class name but is preceded by a tilde.

questions.question: A destructor is preceded by which symbol?
questions.explanation: The destructor is a member function whose name is the same as the class name but is preceded by a tilde (~). For example: ~student();

questions.question: How many destructors can a class have?
questions.explanation: A class can have any number of constructors but only one destructor at a time.

questions.question: Does a destructor take any arguments?
options: No, it never takes any argument
questions.explanation: Destructor never takes any argument nor does it return any value. It will be invoked by the compiler upon exit from the program to clean the storage.

questions.question: When is a destructor automatically invoked?
options: Upon exit from the program or function or block
When a member function is called
questions.explanation: Destructor will be invoked by the compiler upon exit from the program (or function or block) to clean the storage.

questions.question: Where should a constructor be declared?
questions.explanation: Constructor should be declared in the public section. It does not have any return data type hence it cannot return any values.

questions.question: What happens if no constructor is defined in a class?
options: The compiler supplies a default constructor
questions.explanation: If no constructor is defined, then the compiler supplies a default constructor. In that case, it is called nothing-to-do constructor.

questions.question: In constructor with default arguments, where should default values be placed?
questions.explanation: In constructor with default arguments, all default values should be on the right side. For example: student(int rn, int total = 0);

questions.question: When both default constructor and constructor with default argument exist, what happens?
questions.explanation: When both forms are used in a class (default constructor and constructor with one default argument), it causes ambiguity for a statement such as 'student si;'

questions.question: How are member functions stored in memory?
options: Created and placed only once, shared by all objects
questions.explanation: The member functions are created and placed in the memory space only once when they are defined in class specification. All the objects belonging to that class use the same member functions.

questions.question: How is memory allocated for member variables?
questions.explanation: Space for member variable is allocated separately for each object because member variable holds different value for different objects.

questions.question: Which of the following creates an array of objects?
questions.explanation: The statement 'emp e[10];' creates an array of 10 objects, namely e[0], e[1], ..., e[9].

questions.question: What does the statement 'S2 = S1;' do when S1 and S2 are objects?
options: Assigns the value of S1 to S2, member by member
questions.explanation: The statement 'S2 = S1;' does not invoke the copy constructor. However, it simply assigns the value of S1 to S2, member by member.

questions.question: Which statement invokes the copy constructor?
questions.explanation: The statement 'student S2(S1);' uses copy constructor and initializes an object S2 from another object S1. Another form is 'student S2 = S1;' during declaration.

questions.question: What is the purpose of declaring a destructor?
options: To release memory space for future use
questions.explanation: It is a good practice to declare destructor in a program because it releases memory space for future use.

questions.question: The keywords public, private and protected are called:
questions.explanation: The keywords public, private and protected are called as visibility modes/access specifiers.

questions.question: Which members can be accessed from outside the class?
questions.explanation: The data member and member functions present in public mode can be accessed within the class and also by other class of same program.

questions.question: When a member function is defined inside a class, it is considered:
questions.explanation: When a member function is defined inside a class, it is considered to be inline by default. If a member function is very small then it should be defined inside the class.

questions.question: What is the correct syntax for accessing array element in an array of objects?
questions.explanation: The statement 'e[i].getdata()' will get the data of the ith element of the array e, where e is an array of objects.

questions.question: A class specification has how many parts?
questions.explanation: A class specification has two parts: (i) Class declaration and (ii) Class function definitions.

questions.question: What terminates the class body?
questions.explanation: The body of the class is enclosed between braces and terminated by semicolon.

questions.question: Which of the following can access private and protected members?
questions.explanation: The data member and member functions present in private and protected mode can be accessed by the member function in public mode.

questions.question: The two methods to call parameterized constructor are:
questions.explanation: When the object is created, we must supply arguments to the constructor function. This can be done in two ways: by calling the function explicitly and by calling the function implicitly.

questions.question: What happens when actual parameter is provided in constructor with default arguments?
options: Actual parameter takes priority over default parameter
questions.explanation: When both actual and default parameters are provided, actual parameter takes the priority over default parameter. For example, in student S2(3, 75), 3 is assigned to rn and 75 to total.

questions.question: Which statement correctly defines a member function outside the class?
questions.explanation: When defining a member function outside the class, the scope resolution operator :: is used. The format is: return_type class_name::function_name

questions.question: What type of functions are collectively called members?
options: Both variables and functions declared in class
questions.explanation: The class body contains the declaration of variables and functions. These are collectively called members. The variables are called data members and functions are called member functions.

questions.question: In object-oriented programming, emphasis is on:
questions.explanation: In object oriented programming, the emphasis is on data rather than function. Class is a way that binds the data & function together.

questions.question: When is a constructor automatically invoked?
options: When a member function is called
questions.explanation: A constructor is invoked automatically whenever an object is created. It is called constructor because it constructs the values of data members of the class.

questions.question: What does 'nothing-to-do constructor' refer to?
options: A compiler-supplied default constructor when no constructor is defined
questions.explanation: If no constructor is defined, then the compiler supplies a default constructor. In that case, it is called nothing-to-do constructor.
